– September 17, 2020 – Assailing “left-wing demonstrators” and “far-left mobs,” Trump called for the creation of a “[1776 Commission](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/17/us/politics/trump-patriotic-education.html)” to “restore patriotic education to our schools.” Speaking at the National Archives Museum, he said, “Our heroes will never be forgotten. Our youth will be taught to love America.”

– September 17, 2020 – Taking a rare political stance for a U.S. attorney general, William Barr [likened stay-at-home orders to house arrest](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/17/william-barr-coronavirus-lockdowns-slavery-416776). “It’s — you know, other than slavery, which was a different kind of restraint, this is the greatest intrusion on civil liberties in American history,” he said. “As an attorney general, I’m not supposed to get into politics,” he said. But, he added, “I think we were getting into a position where we were going to find ourselves irrevocably committed to the socialist path and I think if Trump loses this election that — that will be the case.”

– September 17, 2020 – Amy Dorris, a former model, said that Trump [sexually assaulted her](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/ex-model-amy-dorris-alleges-trump-sexually-assaulted-her-1997-n1240291) in 1997 at the U.S. Open tennis tournament; he was 51 and she was 24. “He just shoved his tongue down my throat and I was pushing him off,” she said. “And then that’s when his grip became tighter and his hands were very gropey and all over my butt, my breasts, my back, everything.”

– September 17, 2020 – Trump’s properties [took in more than $1.1 million that it charged the government](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/secret-service-spending-bedminster/2020/09/17/9e11e1c2-f6a0-11ea-be57-d00bb9bc632d_story.html) while he was in office. The  said that the Trump Organization made some of that money off of room rentals at Trump’s club in Bedminster, N.J., when the business was shut down during the pandemic. Before assuming office, Trump vowed to “completely isolate” himself from his business. While in office, however, he visited his properties 274 times.

– September 17, 2020 – Olivia Troye, Vice President Pence’s former homeland security adviser, claimed that Trump once said, in a meeting, “[Maybe this covid thing is a good thing](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/09/17/devastating-picture-trumps-coronavirus-response-firsthand-witness/). I don’t like shaking hands with people. I don’t have to shake hands with these disgusting people.”

– September 18, 2020 – Health officials estimated that Americans would not get a coronavirus vaccine before mid-2021, but Trump [insisted that everyone could get doses by April](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/09/18/trump-coronavirus-vaccine-april-417835). “We essentially have it — we will be announcing it soon,” he said. Just a few days earlier, he said the vaccine would be available by March.

– September 21, 2020 – The Justice Department [designated Portland, Oregon, New York and Seattle](https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/justice-dept-targets-new-york-seattle-and-portland-over-protests/2020/09/21/9e85e46a-fc08-11ea-b555-4d71a9254f4b_story.html) as “jurisdictions that have permitted violence and destruction of property to persist” — and that risk having their federal funding cut.

– September 22, 2020 – As the nation’s death toll from the coronavirus reached 200,000 people, Trump declared at a rally in Ohio that the virus “[affects virtually nobody](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/22/us/politics/trump-coronavirus-virtually-nobody.html).”

– September 22, 2020 – Congress in March approved $1 billion for the Pentagon to “prevent, prepare for, and respond to coronavirus,” including making more masks and medical equipment available. Instead, the Defense Department [gave most of the money to defense contractors](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/09/22/covid-funds-pentagon/) for jet engine parts and other military supplies.

– September 23, 2020 – Claiming once again that mail-in voting was fraudulent, Trump said that if he lost the election, [he would not commit to a peaceful transfer of power](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-transfer-of-power/2020/09/23/be6954d0-fdf0-11ea-b555-4d71a9254f4b_story.html). “Well, we’re going to have to see what happens,” he said.

– September 27, 2020 – Trump [paid only $750 in federal income taxes in 2016 and in 2017](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/09/27/us/donald-trump-taxes.html) — and received an income tax refund of $72.9 million after declaring large losses. According to a  investigation, Trump is $421 million in debt. He once boasted that his tax returns were “very big” and “beautiful,” but he has for years refused to release his returns.

– September 29, 2020 – In their first presidential debate, Trump [interrupted Biden almost every time the Democratic candidate spoke](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/29/us/politics/trump-biden-debate.html), prompting debate moderator Chris Wallace to plead with the president to be quiet. When Biden asked Trump if he would be willing to condemn the Proud Boys, a group of white supremacists who endorse violence, the president refused. Instead, he called on them to “Stand back and stand by.” Trump also ridiculed Biden for wearing what he called “the biggest mask I’ve ever seen.”

– September 29, 2020 – The White House [contacted Amy Coney Barrett](https://apnews.com/article/election-2020-virus-outbreak-donald-trump-ruth-bader-ginsburg-amy-coney-barrett-4b50c5a95588ab80d88dbe0803a3a729) about being a Supreme Court nominee only a day after Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg died on September 18. On September 21, Barrett accepted Trump’s offer to be the nominee, four days before Ginsburg was to lie in state in the U.S. Capitol.

– October 1, 2020 – In a secret 2018 recording made by her former friend and adviser Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, Melania Trump [belittled the fate of migrant children taken from their parents at the Mexican border](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/01/us/politics/melania-trump-tapes.html?searchResultPosition=1). “Give me a fucking break,” she said. “Were they were saying anything when Obama did that?” She also complained about having to work during the holidays. “I’m working like a — my ass off at Christmas stuff,” she said. “You know, who gives a fuck about Christmas stuff and decoration?”

– October 2, 2020 – In a tweet he sent at nearly 1 a.m. — just 32 days before the election — Trump said that [he and the first lady had tested positive for the coronavirus](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/02/us/politics/trump-covid.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage). The president’s announcement followed months of his downplaying a disease that has killed more than 207,000 Americans and plunged the nation into an economic crisis. Dr. Sean Conley, the White House physician, wrote in a memo that Trump was doing “very well.” Aides, however, said that Trump was coughing and had a fever, and he was flown by helicopter to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. Over the coming days, more than a dozen people who had attended events at the White House or on the campaign trail contracted the virus. They included Trump advisers Hope Hicks and Stephen Miller, U.S. Senators Thom Tillis and Mike Lee, White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany, former White House counselor Kellyanne Conway, Republican National Committee Chairwoman Ronna McDaniel, former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, and University of Notre Dame President John Jenkins.

– October 3, 2020 – White House physician Sean Conley again said Trump was “doing very well,” yet he was contradicted minutes later by Mark Meadows, Trump’s chief of staff. Citing a fever and a drop in blood oxygen level, Meadows said, “[The president’s vitals over the last 24 hours were very concerning](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/03/world/trump-says-he-feels-better-but-his-chief-of-staff-says-he-is-still-not-on-a-clear-path-to-a-full-recovery.html).”

– October 3, 2020 – Even though he was infected with a deadly virus, Trump [defied public health guidelines](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-covid-19-walter-reed-wave/2020/10/04/12dbe38c-064f-11eb-a166-dc429b380d10_story.html) and left Walter Reed National Military Medical Center to greet supporters from a slow-moving  — he said he was bored of being in the hospital. In the vehicle with Trump were several Secret Service agents. Health professionals said the agents were at risk of contracting the virus while in such a closed environment. Speaking anonymously for fear of retribution, one agent said about Trump: “He’s not even pretending to care now.”

– October 5, 2020 – Trump’s doctor said he “may not be entirely out of the woods yet,” but the president chose to leave the hospital to return to the White House. “[Don’t be afraid of COVID](https://www.washingtonpost.com/elections/2020/10/05/trump-biden-live-updates/),” he said of the virus that has claimed the lives of more than 209,000 Americans. “Don’t let it dominate your life.” Arriving at the White House, Trump climbed stairs to a balcony and made a point of pulling off his mask for a photo-op. He then entered the White House, endangering the lives of the hundreds of people who work there.

– October 6, 2020 – Five U.S. attorneys expressed concerns about separating immigrant children from their parents along the Mexican border. According to a recent draft report, then-U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions dismissed what they had to say. “[We need to take away children](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/06/us/politics/family-separation-border-immigration-jeff-sessions-rod-rosenstein.html),” he told the U.S. attorneys — regardless of how young they are.

– October 7, 2020 – The coronavirus outbreak at the White House [infected 34 people](https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/34-people-connected-white-house-previously-infected-coronavirus/story?id=73487381), making the executive mansion a super-spreader location and one of the densest concentrations of -19 in the Washington, D.C. area. Trump did not wear a mask after his return from the hospital, nor did several aides who were seen working closely together at the White House.

– October 7, 2020 – In a video he posted on Twitter, Trump said the drug he was given to treat the coronavirus was a “[cure](https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/10/07/us/trump-covid-19-live-latest#rejecting-rest-and-recuperation-trump-aims-to-show-hes-in-charge)” — the drug, however is unapproved. As for contracting the coronavirus, he said, “I think this was a blessing from God that I caught it.”

– October 8, 2020 – Only six days after he revealed that he was infected with the coronavirus, Trump [refused to take part in a second debate](https://www.axios.com/trump-biden-debate-remote-coronavirus-c57f521e-fca5-46d8-aeed-9ec2ca1b3c2b.html) with Joe Biden unless it was in person. “I’m not going to waste my time on a virtual debate,” he said. “It’s ridiculous, and then they cut you off whenever they want.”

– October 8, 2020 – Speaking publicly at length for the first time since testing positive for the coronavirus, Trump [lashed out at Cabinet members and his political rivals](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/08/us/politics/trump-calls-to-indict-political-rivals.html?referringSource=articleShare). “I’m not happy about him,” Trump said about Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, citing Pompeo’s failure to release Hillary Clinton’s emails. In an interview with Fox, the president added that William Barr’s legacy would be tainted if the attorney general did not indict Joe Biden and Barack Obama. He also called vice presidential candidate Kamala Harris “a monster” and a “communist.” Speaking about the coronavirus, Trump said that he might have [contracted it when meeting with relatives of fallen service members](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-points-slain-veteran-families-response-questions-about-how-he-n1242624) — even though a veterans’ group maintained that none of those people got sick after visiting the White House. “I went through like 35 people,” he said. “They come within an inch of my face sometimes. They want to hug me and they want to kiss me. And they do. And frankly, I’m not telling them to back up. I’m not doing it. But I did say it’s obviously dangerous. It’s a dangerous thing, if you go by the Covid thing.”

– October 8, 2020 – Doctors at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center [were told to sign nondisclosure agreements](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-walter-reed-nondisclosure-agreements/2020/10/08/50dbb71a-073b-11eb-a166-dc429b380d10_story.html) when Trump visited the hospital for an unscheduled visit in November 2019. The unusual requirement angered staff members, who said they respect patient confidentiality. Trump’s last-minute visit was unscheduled, but the White House called it a “routine” checkup.

– October 8, 2020 – Elliott Broidy, a top Trump fund-raiser, was charged with [conspiring to violate lobbying laws](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/08/us/politics/elliott-broidy-trump-fundraiser.html?searchResultPosition=1). A defense contractor, Broidy was accused of accepting $6 million from a foreign client to lobby the Trump administration. In 2018, Broidy resigned as deputy finance chairman of the Republican National Committee — after it was revealed that he agreed to pay $1.6 million to a former Playboy model to keep quiet about their affair. The deal was overseen by Trump’s personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, who was later sentenced to prison for financial and political crimes.

– October 9, 2020 – The Trump administration [blocked the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention from requiring masks on public transportation throughout the country](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/09/health/coronavirus-covid-masks-cdc.html). The mandate had the backing of Alex Azar, the secretary of health and human services, but Vice President Mike Pence, who heads the White House Coronavirus Task Force, refused to even address it.

– October 10, 2020 – When running for president, Trump said he would “completely isolate” himself from the Trump Organization. But a  investigation found that as president, Trump has been [involved in scores of events at his properties](https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/10/10/us/trump-properties-swamp.html). In the first two years of his presidency, they delivered roughly $12 million of business to his company.

– October 12, 2020 – Trump addressed supporters at an airport hanger in Florida, claiming — without any scientific evidence — that [he was immune to the coronavirus](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/12/us/politics/trump-rally-florida.html). “I feel so powerful,” he said. “I’ll kiss everyone in that audience. I’ll kiss the guys and the beautiful women. Just give you a big fat kiss.”

– October 12, 2020 – Every time Trump’s children visited his properties, the U.S. government had to pay his company for the Secret Service agents who stayed with them. According to the , the Trump Organization [earned at least $238,000 in taxpayer money](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/secret-service-spending-trump-kids/2020/10/12/ffc1c330-ff31-11ea-9ceb-061d646d9c67_story.html) by charging the government. The children’s visits to Trump’s resorts and hotels included overseas golf trips. Ivanka Trump repeatedly brought her Secret Service agents to the Trump golf club in Bedminster, N.J. — at a time when she appealed to Americans to “please, please” stay home during the pandemic.

– October 13, 2020 – During the coronavirus outbreak at the White House, the Trump administration [backed a petition that defends the concept of herd immunity](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/13/world/white-house-embraces-a-declaration-from-scientists-that-opposes-lockdowns-and-relies-on-herd-immunity.html). The offices of the Manhattan district attorney and the New York state attorney general issued subpoenas to the Trump Organization in both investigations.

– November 20, 2020 – Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s attorney, [baselessly alleged](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/rudy-giuliani-baselessly-alleges-centralized-voter-fraud-free-wheeling-news-n1248273) that “mass cheating” occurred during the election. “It’s not a singular voter fraud in one state,” Giuliani said. “This pattern repeats itself in a number of states, almost exactly the same pattern, which… suggests that there was a plan — from a centralized place to execute these various acts of voter fraud, specifically focused on big cities, and specifically focused on, as you would imagine, big cities controlled by Democrats, and particularly if they focused on big cities that have a long history of corruption.” The Trump campaign’s allegations of fraud have already been debunked.

– November 20, 2020 –  In an unprecedented meeting, Trump [summoned Michigan’s Senate Majority Leader Mike Shirkey and House Speaker Lee Chatfield to the White House](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-michigan-lawmakers-meeting/2020/11/20/ef30e2ba-2b43-11eb-8fa2-06e7cbb145c0_story.html) in a brazen attempt to keep the state from certifying Joe Biden’s win. But Shirkey and Chatfield, both Republicans, later issued a statement that said, “We will follow the law and follow the normal process regarding Michigan’s electors, just as we have said throughout this election.”

– November 21, 2020 – A federal judge dismissed the Trump campaign’s lawsuit to block Pennsylvania’s certification of its election results, but [Trump’s legal team said it would appeal the decision](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/us-judge-dismisses-trump-campaign-lawsuit-in-pa/2020/11/21/cc097fbe-2c50-11eb-9b14-ad872157ebc9_story.html). In its attempt to invalidate millions of votes, U.S. District Judge Matthew W. Brann wrote that Trump’s campaign had used “strained legal arguments without merit and speculative accusations,” adding, “In the United States of America, this cannot justify the disenfranchisement of a single voter, let alone all the voters of its sixth most populated state.”

– November 22, 2020 – Sidney Powell, a member of Trump’s legal team, said that a Trump campaign lawsuit over election results in Georgia “[will be biblical](https://www.newsweek.com/trump-lawyer-sidney-powell-says-georgia-election-lawsuit-will-biblical-suggests-gop-governor-1549333).” In an interview with the conservative Newsmax TV, she said, “Georgia’s probably going to be the first state I’m gonna blow up. We’ve got tons of evidence. It’s so much, it’s hard to pull it all together.” In another interview, on Fox Business Network, Powell said, “[I’m going to release the Kraken](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/17/technology/release-the-kraken-a-catchphrase-for-unfounded-conspiracy-theory-trends-on-twitter.html)” — a catchphrase that has become popular on social media among election fraud conspiracy theorists. Powell had also alleged that a “massive influence of communist money through Venezuela, Cuba and likely China” interfered with the election in favor of Joe Biden. By week’s end, Trump’s other lawyers cut her from their legal team, releasing a statement that said, “Sidney Powell is practicing law on her own.”

– November 22, 2020 – Trump briefly took part in a virtual Group of 20 summit, but [he skipped a conference on the pandemic](https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/11/21/us/joe-biden-trump#president-trump-makes-brief-appearance-at-group-of-20-but-skips-pandemic-meeting) attended by, among others, French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Angela Merkel. On the day after the United States recorded more than 198,500 cases of the coronavirus — a record — Trump instead went golfing. He has not taken any questions from reporters since the election, but during that time he has gone to his golf resort in Virginia five times.

– November 23, 2020 – Trump said that “in the best interest of our Country,” he approved of allowing Joe Biden to begin his transition to become president. Trump [still refused to concede](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/23/us/politics/trump-transition-biden.html), though, writing on Twitter that “Our case  continues, we will keep up the good fight, and I believe we will prevail!” Nearly three weeks after the election, there was no evidence to support his allegations of election fraud.

– November 24, 2020 –  As record numbers of new -19 cases were being reported, Trump [appeared in the White House briefing room for the first time since the election](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/24/trump-briefing-impromptu-speech-440321) — but for only one minute. “That is a sacred number,” he said, looking to take credit for the Dow Jones Industrial Average crossing 30,000 for the first time. “Nobody thought they’d ever see it.” He then abruptly left the room without taking any questions.

– November 25, 2020 – Trump [pardoned his former national security adviser Michael Flynn](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/michael-flynn-trump-pardon/2020/11/25/3cd79198-2e65-11eb-bae0-50bb17126614_story.html), one of six associates convicted in the investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 election. Flynn had pleaded guilty for lying to the .

– November 26, 2020 – Trump said that he would step down if the Electoral College voted for Joe Biden. The next day, however, [he said Biden](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/11/26/us/politics/trump-election-georgia.html?action=click&module=RelatedLinks&pgtype=Article) “can only enter the White House as President if he can prove that his ridiculous ‘80,000,000 votes’ were not fraudulently or illegally obtained.”

– November 27, 2020 – Trump’s attempt to overturn Pennsylvania’s election results was denied by a federal appeals court. “Voters, not lawyers, choose the President,” Judge Stephanos Bibas wrote in his opinion, saying that Trump’s challenge had “no merit.” Nevertheless, Jenna Ellis, a Trump adviser, said the campaign [would take the case to the Supreme Court](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/federal-appeals-court-rejects-trump-request-for-emergency-injunction-to-overturn-certification-of-pennsylvanias-election-results/2020/11/27/556540ba-30d7-11eb-bae0-50bb17126614_story.html).

– November 29, 2020 –  Despite having lost every court challenge to overturn election results, [Trump told Fox News that he will not accept Joe Biden’s victory](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/my-mind-will-not-change-in-six-months-in-first-post-election-tv-interview-trump-renews-baseless-claims-of-voter-fraud/2020/11/29/5068b4e4-3261-11eb-b59c-adb7153d10c2_story.html). “My mind will not change in six months,” he said. “There was tremendous cheating here.” No election officials, however, have come forward with any evidence of fraud.

– November 30, 2020 – Trump [raised roughly $170 million in donations after the election](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-raises-more-than-150-million-appealing-to-false-election-claims/2020/11/30/82e922e6-3347-11eb-afe6-e4dbee9689f8_story.html), claiming that he needed money for an Official Election Defense Fund — an account that does not exist. “I need you now more than ever,” one fundraising appeal reads. “The Recount Results were .” According to the fine print of the appeals, however, most of the money will go to a new political action committee to fund future political activities.

– November 30, 2020 – Joe DiGenova, Trump’s campaign lawyer, said Christopher Krebs, the former head of U.S. cybersecurity should be “[shot](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/30/trump-campaign-lawyer-cybersecurity-chief-shot-441577).” Trump fired his director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency five days after the agency said there was no evidence that any voting system was “in any way compromised” in the election. “Anybody who thinks the election went well, like that idiot Krebs who used to be the head of cybersecurity, that guy is a class A moron,” DiGenova said. “He should be drawn and quartered. Taken out at dawn and shot.”

– December 2, 2020 – In a [46-minute videotaped speech](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/02/us/politics/trump-election-video.html), Trump railed against the “tremendous voter fraud” of an election system that he said was “under coordinated assault and siege.” A day earlier, his own attorney general, William Barr, said, “to date, we have not seen fraud on a scale that could have affected a different outcome in the election.”

– December 2, 2020 – The Trump administration [helped wealthy companies benefit from the Treasury Department’s coronavirus emergency fund](https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/12/01/ppp-sba-data/) that was intended for small businesses. More than half of the $522 billion for small businesses went to larger companies.

– December 4, 2020 – The Trump administration [rejected attempts by Joe Biden’s transition team to meet U.S. intelligence officials](https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/pentagon-blocks-biden-transition-team/2020/12/04/2e7042fa-3656-11eb-a997-1f4c53d2a747_story.html), impeding Biden’s ability to gain crucial knowledge of classified operations around the world. Trump’s action comes despite the General Services Administration giving Biden’s team access to federal agencies on November 23.

– December 4, 2020 – Trump Victory — a fundraising committee for the president, [spent more than $1 million at his properties](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/12/04/trump-spending-properties/) in the past three months — creating revenue at a time when hotels’ profits have fallen because of the pandemic. During his presidency, Trump’s campaign has spent $6.7 million in donations at his businesses.

– December 5, 2020 – In his latest attempt to reverse his election loss, [Trump asked Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp to push the state legislature to overturn Joe Biden’s victory in Georgia](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-kemp-call-georgia/2020/12/05/fd8d677c-3721-11eb-8d38-6aea1adb3839_story.html). The president also tried to have Kemp mandate an audit of absentee ballot signatures, which Kemp had said was not within his power.

– December 6, 2020 – Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s personal lawyer, was [the latest person in the president’s circle to test positive for the coronavirus](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/06/world/rudy-giuliani-covid.html). Like Trump, Giuliani [has downplayed the disease](https://www.forbes.com/sites/jackbrewster/2020/12/10/giuliani-acknowledges-his-celebrity-status-helped-him-receive-preferential-covid-19-treatment/?sh=6b6fcf7cb39b). In October, he told a crowd that “people don’t die of this disease anymore.” At the time, hundreds of people were dying every day.

– December 7, 2020 – James Phillips, an attending physician who criticized Trump for going on a drive-by with Secret Service agents — while the president had -19 — [was removed from the schedule](https://thehill.com/policy/defense/529127-doctor-who-criticized-trumps-behavior-removed-from-walter-reed-schedule-report) of Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.

– December 7, 2020 – The Trump administration, led by a man who for decades has boasted of his skills as a dealmaker, [turned down a chance to secure more doses of Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/07/us/trump-covid-vaccine-pfizer.html). The failure to make a deal with the pharmaceutical giant gave other countries the chance to get in line ahead of the United States, acquiring doses from the American company before the United States could.

– December 8, 2020 – Trump [twice called Bryan Cutler, the Pennsylvania Speaker of the House, in an effort to overturn the election result](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/supreme-court-trump-pennsylvania-election-results/2020/12/08/4d39e16c-397d-11eb-98c4-25dc9f4987e8_story.html). Cutler, however, told Trump that he did not have that authority. The Supreme Court then denied a request by the president’s allies to overturn Pennsylvania’s election results.

– December 8, 2020 – Another of Trump’s personal lawyers, Jenna Ellis, [tested positive for the coronavirus](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/08/trump-lawyer-jenna-ellis-covid-443688) — four days after attending a Christmas party where she mingled with other guests while not wearing a mask.

– December 10, 2020 – Rebuffed by courts and state lawmakers, Trump [called Republican members of Congress in a last-ditch effort to reverse the election](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-republicans-biden-election/2020/12/09/abd596ea-3a4e-11eb-9276-ae0ca72729be_story.html). Mike Pence also made calls to lawmakers on the president’s behalf, as did Rudy Giuliani, who was in the hospital with the coronavirus.

– December 11, 2020 – The Trump administration [carried out its ninth of 13 planned federal executions](https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-donald-trump-race-and-ethnicity-prisons-killeen-13044e3f1ab9e0e140c57d8012b67abb) — the first federal executions since 2003. Trump will have executed more inmates than any other president in more than 130 years. Grover Cleveland, in the 1890s, was the last president to carry out executions during a presidential transition.

– December 11, 2020 – A lawsuit suit filed in the Supreme Court argued on behalf of Trump that the election was “riddled with an unprecedented number of serious allegations of fraud and irregularities.” The court, however, [rejected the suit in a terse, unsigned order](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump/u-s-supreme-court-swiftly-ends-trump-backed-texas-bid-to-upend-election-results-idUSKBN28L2YY). Despite the ruling from the highest court in the land, Rudy Giuliani, Trump’s personal lawyer, said his team would still pursue further legal action.

– December 12, 2020 – Refusing to accept the Supreme Court’s ruling on a case that called the election “rigged,” [Trump tweeted](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1338246404075118595?s=20) that the justices “‘just ’chickened out’ and didn’t want to rule on the merits of the case. So bad for our Country!” He added, without any proof, [I WON THE ELECTION IN A LANDSLIDE](https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1337745268591259648?s=20).”

– December 13, 2020 – Trump said [he would continue to challenge the result of the election](https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/529988-trump-says-election-challenges-not-over), regardless of the Supreme Court’s rejection of a last-minute attempt to overturn Joe Biden’s victory. “No, it’s not over,” he said on . “We keep going.” On Twitter, he repeated his baseless claim that he won the election, writing, “MOST   IN U.S. !”

– December 13, 2020 – The Trump administration [planned to distribute the coronavirus vaccine to its staff](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/13/us/politics/white-house-coronavirus-vaccine-trump.html) — at a time when front-line health care workers were given priority for early doses. Trump, though, reversed the policy hours after it was reported by the .

– December 14, 2020 – Trump [announced that Attorney General William Barr was resigning](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/14/us/politics/william-barr-attorney-general.html), less than two weeks after the attorney general disputed Trump by saying that his department did not uncover any election fraud.

– December 15, 2020 – As the Biden administration prepared to take office in five weeks, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos told employees in her department to “[be the resistance](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/15/betsy-devos-biden-education-department-445900).” Following the lead of a president who has refused to concede the election, she said, “Let me leave you with this plea: Resist.”

– December 15, 2020 – Trump and the Republican National Committee [asked people to donate](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/georgia-senate-election-fund-donations-trump-save-america-political-action-committee/) to a “Georgia Election Fund” for Senators David Perdue and Kelly Loeffler’s campaigns. But the fine print of their fundraising emails reveals that most of the money will go to Save America, Trump’s political action committee.

– December 16, 2020 – Trump appointee Paul Alexander advised health officials to embrace “[herd immunity](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/16/trump-appointee-demanded-herd-immunity-strategy-446408)” — even though it would put millions of Americans’ lives in danger. A former health researcher, Alexander worked for Health and Human Services spokesman Michael Caputo until he left his job in September. In a July 4 email, Alexander wrote, “Infants, kids, teens, young people, young adults, middle aged with no conditions etc. have zero to little risk…we want them infected.”

– December 18, 2020 – Chris Miller, Trump’s acting Defense secretary, [ordered the Pentagon to stop working with Joe Biden’s transition team](https://www.axios.com/pentagon-biden-transition-briefings-123a9658-4af1-4632-a6e6-770117784d60.html). Miller later said that both sides would meet again after “the mutually agreed-upon holiday,” but Biden transition director Yohannes Abraham said, “Let me be clear: there was no mutually agreed-upon holiday break.”

– December 19, 2020 – Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said that Russia was “pretty clearly” responsible for a massive cyber attack on the U.S. government, but Trump instead suggested that China was behind it. “Everything is well under control,” the president said, [downplaying the cybersecurity breach](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/19/us/trump-contradicts-pompeo-over-russias-role-in-hack.html). It was his latest refusal to find fault with anything that might lay blame at the feet of the Russian government.

– December 20, 2020 – Trump’s campaign [filed a new petition with the Supreme Court, seeking to overturn Pennsylvania’s election results](https://apnews.com/article/trump-supreme-court-election-results-151f9a6ca176bd92bb67e4494fecc3c7) — despite the fact that the state had already certified Joe Biden as the winner of its Electoral College votes.

– December 21, 2020 – Trump [spoke with aides about appointing his former attorney, Sidney Powell, as special counsel to investigate supposed voter fraud](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/21/us/politics/barr-trump-hunter-biden-election.html). But William Barr, the president’s outgoing attorney general, said he saw no reason to do so. “I’m not going to,” he said.

– December 21, 2020 – Trump met with Mike Pence and a dozen congressional Republicans at the White House, [strategizing for more than three hours about how to overturn the results of the presidential election](http://politico.com/news/2020/12/21/trump-house-overturn-election-449787). The Electoral College, however, confirmed Joe Biden as the next president on December 14.

– December 22, 2020 – With less than a month remaining in his term, Trump [issued 15 pardons and five commutations](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/22/us/politics/trump-pardons.html). He granted clemency to three convicted former Republican lawmakers, two men who lied to investigators in Robert Mueller’s Russia inquiry, and four Blackwater guards who were convicted of killing Iraqi civilians in a 2007 massacre — among those shot to death were two boys, ages 8 and 11.

– December 23, 2020 – Trump [granted clemency to 29 more people](https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/charles-kushner-paul-manafort-roger-stone-trump-pardons/2020/12/23/05cf013a-456d-11eb-975c-d17b8815a66d_story.html). They included loyalists who committed fraud and lied to investigators in order to help the president. Charles Kushner, a real estate developer and the father of Trump’s son-in-law, was pardoned by Trump — Kushner pleaded guilty in 2004 to witness tampering and tax evasion. Trump also pardoned Paul Manafort, his former campaign chairman who was convicted of tax fraud, bank fraud and conspiracy. And the president pardoned Roger Stone, his longtime friend and 2016 campaign chairman who was convicted of witness tampering, lying to Congress, and obstructing the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

– December 27, 2020 – Trump signed a $900 billion pandemic relief package, but the fact that he [stalled on the bill for several days](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/27/us/politics/trump-signs-pandemic-relief.html) — threatening a government shutdown — meant that unemployment benefits for millions of Americans would be delayed.

– December 31, 2020 – Operation Warp Speed, the public–private partnership announced by Trump, had a goal of vaccinating 20 million Americans by the end of the year. [By January 1, only 2.8 million people got a shot to prevent the coronavirus](https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2020/12/31/coronavirus-covid-updates/).

– January 1, 2021 – Hundreds of people, most not wearing masks despite the raging pandemic, [attended Trump’s annual black-tie party at his private Florida club](https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/01/politics/mar-a-lago-new-years-eve/index.html), Mar-a-Lago. The guests paid up to $1,000 each to attend, dancing to music performed by Vanilla Ice. Trump skipped the gala.

– January 1, 2021 – Trump [sought to invalidate Georgia’s crucial Senate runoff races](https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/532348-trump-claims-georgia-senate-runoff-is-both-illegal-and-invalid-in-new-years), calling them “illegal and invalid.” The two Jan. 5 elections will determine which party controls the U.S. Senate. Contrary to Trump’s claims, there is no evidence that the races have been fraudulent.

– January 3, 2021 – Trump urged Georgia’s secretary of state to “find” votes in order to overturn Joe Biden’s victory in the state. In a one-hour recording of a phone call, [Trump angrily tried to coerce Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-raffensperger-call-georgia-vote/2021/01/03/d45acb92-4dc4-11eb-bda4-615aaefd0555_story.html), potentially violating state and federal law. “So look,” the president said. “All I want to do is this. I just want to find 11,780 votes, which is one more than we have. Because we won the state.” During the call, Raffensperger and his office’s attorney, Ryan Germany, asserted that Biden’s victory in Georgia was fair. But Trump warned Raffensperger, a fellow Republican, that if he did not do what the president asked, the secretary of state would be taking “a big risk.” Trump added: “So what are we going to do here, folks? I only need 11,000 votes. Fellas, I need 11,000 votes. Give me a break.”

– January 4, 2021 – At a Georgia rally intended to boost the candidacies of Senators David Perdue and Kelly Loeffler, Trump instead complained about his own fate and [insisted that he would remain in office](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/04/us/politics/trump-georgia-rally.html). “There’s no way we lost Georgia,” he said, even though Joe Biden won the state by 11,779 votes. “They’re not going to take this White House,” he added. “We’re going to fight like hell, I’ll tell you right now.”

– January 5, 2021 – Trump [claimed](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/05/us/politics/pence-trump-election.html) that when Congress meets to certify election results on January 6, his vice president “has the power to reject fraudulently chosen electors” — and therefore overturn the election. The Constitution says no such thing.

– January 6, 2021 – Hours after Trump [incited a crowd at a rally](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trump-supporters-storm-capitol-dc/2021/01/06/58afc0b8-504b-11eb-83e3-322644d82356_story.html?arc404=true) — urging supporters to “fight” and march to the Capitol — a riotous mob stormed the halls of Congress in an attempted coup. In an unprecedented attack on the heart of the nation’s legislative branch, thousands of Trump extremists clashed with police, breached barricades, climbed walls, smashed through doors and windows, and swarmed into the Capitol, vandalizing offices and occupying both chambers of Congress, where lawmakers had been certifying Joe Biden’s election. Amid the chaos, lawmakers and others in the building were forced to flee to safety, donning gas masks for protection. Police drew their guns in the House chamber in an effort to block rioters from entering the room. They also fired tear gas into the Rotunda, where rioters gathered, taking selfies and waving Confederate and Trump flags. Four died before police and the National Guard were able to restore order: one woman was shot by police and three suffered medical emergencies. A Capitol police officer later died of injuries sustained during the riot. Rather than address the nation on television, denouncing the insurrection, Trump waited for hours before posting a video on Twitter. In it, he told rioters, “We love you. You’re very special.”

– January 7, 2021 – Trump told aides that he is thinking of [pardoning himself](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/07/us/politics/trump-self-pardon.html). In numerous talks with advisers since the election, he asked how such a move could help him. It is unclear what legal protection a self-pardon might provide since Trump would be the first president to issue one.

– January 7, 2021 – In a pre-recorded video, Trump publicly acknowledged for the first time that he was leaving the White House. “A new administration will be inaugurated on January 20,” he said with little conviction, reading from a teleprompter. He did not congratulate President-elect Joe Biden. He also added, "I totally disagree with the outcome of the election.” A Trump adviser said that the president only agreed to record the video after being urged to do so by staffers — and only because he faced possible impeachment for inciting the attack on the Capitol. In the video, however, Trump [neither took responsibility for the insurrection nor said anything about Brian D. Sicknick](https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/07/politics/trump-biden-us-capitol-electoral-college-insurrection/index.html), the Capitol Hill police officer who died after a rioter struck him in the head with a fire extinguisher.

– January 8, 2021 – Trump said on Twitter that he would [not attend President-elect Joe Biden’s inauguration](https://www.washingtonpost.com/history/2021/01/08/andrew-johnson-inauguration-trump-biden/). He would be the first president to skip his successor’s regularly scheduled swearing-in since 1869, when Andrew Johnson, the first president to be impeached, refused to attend Ulysses S. Grant’s inauguration.

– January 12, 2021 – Speaking to the media for the first time since the Capitol insurrection, Trump [expressed no regret for having incited the mob that raided the building](https://www.voanews.com/usa/us-politics/absolutely-ridiculous-trump-says-democrats-impeachment-effort). During his final scheduled presidential trip — a visit to his unfinished border wall — he said that a move to impeach him was “absolutely ridiculous.” He added that his remarks at the rally that preceded the siege were “totally appropriate.”

– January 13, 2021 – Trump [tried one last time to have his vice president overturn the presidential election](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/12/us/politics/mike-pence-trump.html). He called Mike Pence before the Vice President headed to the Capitol to oversee the certification of Joe Biden’s election. “You can either go down in history as a patriot,” Trump angrily told him, “or you can go down in history as a pussy.”

– January 13, 2021 – Rather than address the insurrection at a press conference, Trump — banned from Twitter and other social media platforms — released a statement. “That is not what I stand for, and it is not what America stands for,” he said, [not acknowledging that he had instigated his supporters to storm the Capitol](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-statement/trump-tries-to-head-off-new-demonstrations-among-his-supporters-idUSKBN29I2S2).

– January 13, 2021 – One week after the deadly attack that he incited, Trump was impeached by the House of Representatives. He became the [first president in American history to be impeached twice](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/01/13/trump-impeachment-biden-transition-live-updates/#link-QM7FNFBHFZAQJLK6GFMREIIS3E). In a video released after the House impeached him, Trump sought to distance himself from the violence of the siege. “Making America great again has always been about defending the rule of law,” he said, overlooking the fact that he had exhorted supporters at his January 6 rally to march to the Capitol and “fight.”

– January 15, 2021 – Trump [met at the White House with My Pillow chief executive officer Michael Lindell](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/01/15/pillow-salesman-apparently-has-some-ideas-about-declaring-martial-law/), a  donor who has claimed that Trump won the election. A photograph of notes that the businessman was holding showed text that read, in part, “martial law if necessary,” suggesting that Lindell was advocating military force to keep Trump in office. Although Trump set aside time to meet Lindell, the president has not held a coronavirus task force meeting in months.

– January 19, 2021 – In one of his last acts as president, Trump [issued late-night pardons to Steve Bannon and other allies](https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/19/us/inauguration-day-biden#trump-pardons-bannon). Bannon, Trump’s former chief strategist, was charged with cheating donors who thought their money was going toward the construction of a border wall. He had not yet been tried, and the rare pre-emptive pardon would protect him from any conviction. In his final round of pardons, Trump granted clemency to 143 people in all, including Elliott Broidy, a fund-raiser who violated foreign lobbying laws, and Rick Renzi and Robert Hayes, both former House Republicans. – January 20, 2021 – On his final day in office, Trump [did not invite Joe and Jill Biden to the White House](https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/01/20/us/biden-inauguration#trump-departs-white-house), rejecting a longstanding tradition among presidents and their successors. Rather than attend the inauguration of his successor — making him the first president in modern history to skip the ceremony — Trump headed to Joint Base Andrews. There, a small crowd gathered to see him off. Not among them was Trump’s vice president. “We were not a regular administration,” Trump said in unscripted remarks. “Have a good life, we will see you soon.” As the Village People’s “Y.M.C.A.” played in the background, Trump then boarded Air Force One and returned to his resort in Florida.
